Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Dynamics of Neural Circuits Governing Locomotory Decisions in C.elegans
Award.AbstractNarration: In this project, using novel experimental technique and theoretical tools from condensed matter physics, the PI will address the questions of how the dynamics of neuronal circuits lead to behavior and how neuronal circuits make decisions. The goal of the research is to study how information is coded in the dynamics of a circuit of five pairs of interneurons and how this circuit controls the locomotory behavior of the nematode C. elegans. The project will use confocal fluorescence microscopy in conjunction with a novel system that the PI has developed for an all-optical interrogation of neural circuits in vivo. The results from quantitative experiments will be used to distinguish between models of how information is coded in the activity of each of the ten neurons, measure the bandwidth of the information channel from each of these neurons to the motor output, model the dynamics of the interneuron circuit and determine if it can make locomotory decisions and sustain spontaneous activity. The goal of the educational part of the proposal is to improve the mathematical skills of biology majoring students, inculcate quantitative thinking and promote research at the interface of physics and biology. To do so, the PI will develop an undergraduate course to teach mathematics to biologists, promote quantitative research through undergraduate internships, graduate student and postdoctoral fellow mentoring and help incorporate basic quantitative methods into biology education at the high school level. The PI will devote resources to develop material for both high school students and teachers to inform and excite them about the opportunities in inter-disciplinary research and to help in teaching mathematics using examples from biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How the brain controls our behavior is a fundamental question.

The project set out to understand how neural activity patterns control behavior in an animal that has only 302 neurons and thus is a model system in which to understand how neural circuits sense and process information. 

To achieve our goals, we developed novel microscopy methods. We also developed novel mathematical and experimental methods to determine which neurons were important for controlling specific behaviors. We further developed novel methods to determine how gene expression patterns regulated neural identity.

As a result we could measure and perturb neural activity in the nervous system to understand how the nervous system of the small nematode C.elegans produces behavior. We developed novel statistical methods to rapidly identify the crucial neurons in the circuit that are essential for specific behaviors. We developed molecular techniques to determine the gene expression patterns in neurons as the animal develops to understand how the brain is built. The results from the last two findings are currently being summarized in manuscripts being prepared for submission.

The results of the support from the NSF led to a fundamental understanding of the neurons that control food search behavior in c.elegans. Further, it led to an unexpected outcome: through the development of single cell RNA sequencing, and modeling techniques, we also uncovered novel methods to understand human brain development. The results of all of these studies led to several publications (in addition to the 2 manuscripts that are in preparation and mentioned in the previous paragraph) in leading journals including Nature, Cell Stem Cell, Nature Methods, 2 papers in eLife and 1 paper in Neuron. We believe that our findings will open doors to better understand how the brain is built and how it functions.
